summary: This is an FBI Miami Division memorandum requesting scanning and automation assistance from the Document Conversion Laboratory for telephone records related to the obstruction of justice investigation of Alfredo Rodriguez. Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager, attempted to sell an address book believed to contain contact information for additional underage victims of Epstein.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of an FBI obstruction of justice case opened in October 2009. He came into possession of an address book with names and numbers of potential underage victims of Epstein and attempted to sell it.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: The individual for whom Rodriguez worked. The address book Rodriguez possessed is believed to contain contact information for additional underage victims of Epstein.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: FBI opens obstruction case against Rodriguez
events.description: Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: Timeframe for telephone records
events.description: Telephone records generated between September 1, 2001, and the present (June 2010) are relevant to the investigation.

keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Epstein's former house manager, attempted to sell an address book containing names and telephone numbers of what are believed to be additional, previously unknown underage victims of Jeffrey Epstein.
The FBI opened an obstruction of justice case against Rodriguez in October 2009 for attempting to sell the address book rather than turning it over in response to federal subpoenas.

The document is a request for the FBI's Document Conversion Laboratory to scan and process telephone records (target number 702-743-0620) from the address book for incorporation into the Bureau's Telephone Application (TA) investigative tool.
The address book and its records are believed to contain contact information belonging to Epstein, his associates, or potential underage victims.
The records are to be handled as unclassified, but the scanning process involves systems classified up to SECRET level.
